awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms of DNA Demethylation: The Molecular Interplay Between Thymine DNA Glycosylase and Chromatin Structure
awd_abstract_narration:
DNA is methylated – chemically modified by a methyl group – at specific positions throughout the genome. Establishing and maintaining proper patterns of methylation is a highly choreographed process involving both the addition (methylation) and removal (demethylation) of methyl groups. This project will investigate how some enzymes responsible for demethylating DNA are targeted to specific sites in the genome. This is an important question because accurate demethylation is critical for cellular homeostasis, and dysregulation of this process can result in abnormal development of living organisms as well as diseases such as cancer. The knowledge gained from this research will advance our understanding of how genome methylation landscapes are established and maintained under physiological or pathological states, and may prove useful for future biotechnology applications. Additionally, this project will offer research training opportunities for a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students, enable development of a new educational curriculum, and provide research opportunities to K-12 students to increase participation in STEM fields.

Enzymatic reversal of 5-methylcytosine (5mC) back into cytosine (referred to as “active” DNA demethylation) is an essential pathway in mammals that impacts gene expression and organismal development. As the only known enzyme capable of removing DNA demethylation intermediates 5-formylcytosine and 5-carboxycytosine from DNA in mammals, thymine DNA glycosylase (TDG) has an essential role in the demethylation pathway. Yet, how TDG is targeted to specific genomic loci and how its activities are regulated at these sites remains largely unknown. This project will employ a series of in vitro and mammalian cell studies aimed at uncovering the molecular actions of TDG and how its interactions with chromatin shape genomic methylation landscapes. In vitro studies using chemically defined nucleosome arrays will provide molecular-level details regarding the relationship between TDG activity and chromatin structure. Building on in vitro observations, the biological relevance of TDG-chromatin interactions will be explored in the context of estrogen-responsive gene promoters in cells. The outcomes will advance mechanistic understanding of how chromatin structure impacts TDG activity and thus contributes to methylation dynamics at important gene regulatory elements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
DNA methylation, the chemical addition of a methyl group to DNA, occurs at specific positions throughout the human genome. Establishing and maintaining proper patterns of methylation is a highly choreographed process involving not only the addition of methyl groups, but also their removal (termed DNA demethylation). The overarching goal of this project was to investigate how the enzymes responsible for reversing DNA methylation are targeted to specific sites throughout the genome and how they are controlled once there. These are important questions because accurate DNA demethylation is critical for cellular homeostasis, and dysregulation of this pathway can result in abnormal development and disease, including cancer. Thus, what is learned will advance our understanding of how DNA methylation landscapes are established and maintained under physiological and pathological states, and may prove useful for future clinical applications. Additionally, this project aimed to (1) promote research training for a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students, (2) enable new educational curriculum to be developed, and (3) provide research opportunities to K-12 students to increase participation in STEM fields.

Intellectual Merit. While several enzymes are involved in the DNA demethylation pathway, our study focused specifically on thymine DNA glycosylase (TDG). TDG is the only enzyme known to be capable of removing the important DNA demethylation intermediates 5-formylcytosine (5fC) and 5-carboxycytosine (5caC) from DNA in mammals, and thus, plays a central role in the DNA demethylation pathway. We aimed to identify factors responsible for controlling TDG's activity and to determine how its underlying interactions with nucleic acids (e.g., DNA) and other proteins shape the landscape of DNA methylation throughout our genome. Towards this goal, we discovered several novel properties of TDG that promise to have a lasting impact on how we view this enzyme, its functions, and the DNA demethylation pathway overall:

(1)   The complex mixture of DNA and proteins that form the chromosomes found in the nucleus of human cells is referred to as chromatin. We showed that TDG has the capacity to alter the structure of chromatin through its physical interactions with DNA and, importantly, can induce chromatin phase separation, a key process underlying the organization of our genome. This phenomenon provides an intriguing mechanism whereby chromatin phase separation could be targeted to sites enriched with 5fC and 5caC, the targets of TDG, thereby linking DNA methylation dynamics to genome organization.

(2)   Ribonucleic acid (RNA), the molecular cousin of DNA, has emerged as an important regulator of various cellular pathways. Indeed, prior studies have indicated a potential regulatory relationship between RNA and DNA demethylation, yet the underlying molecular interactions remain unclear. While TDG has been studied for decades as a DNA-binding protein, we discovered that TDG is also capable of binding to RNA and demonstrated that RNA competes with DNA for binding to TDG. Thus, this work provides support for and new insights into a mechanism wherein DNA demethylation is regulated through the direct interactions of TDG with RNA.

(3)   Regulatory RNA can bind directly to genomic DNA in a sequence-dependent manner forming what are referred to as R-loops (DNA/DNA hybrids). These structures have important regulatory functions and have been implicated in controlling DNA demethylation. Remarkably, we found that TDG binds tightly to R-loops and is capable of removing DNA demethylation intermediates 5fC and 5caC from them. These results provide critical support for the role of R-loops in regulating DNA demethylation, as this mechanism requires TDG-mediated excision of 5fC/5caC from such substrates.

Broader Impacts. This project provided graduate student trainees with the skills, knowledge, and experiences necessary for them to excel in their chosen career path. Furthermore, this project greatly broadened participation in and access to science education and research by providing meaningful research opportunities for undergraduate students and through our laboratory's annual participation in the Youth Adventure Program (YAP) at Texas A&M University. YAP is a series of weeklong courses designed to encourage career exploration in STEM fields amongst junior high and high school students. Through specially designed laboratories and demonstrations, students were introduced to the scientific principles behind several important molecular biology techniques, all while obtaining hands-on experience with state-of-the-art equipment and instrumentation. Overall, more than 30 junior high and high school students participated in our YAP course during the award period.
